text.p: We have measured the temperature-dependent resistivity of (TMTTF) PF 6 up to 7 GPa using a turnbuckle-type diamond anvil cell (DAC) and at magnetic fields of up to 5 T. Unlike previous reports on organic compounds, a zero resistance was observed in the superconducting state even at high pressures. Superconductivity was observed in the range of P ¼ 4:18 to 6.03 GPa and showed a peak T c of 2.25 K at 4.58 GPa. The temperature dependence of the upper critical magnetic field H c2 ðT Þ was determined via resistivity at P ¼ 4:58 GPa, for the intrachain (a), interchain (b 0), and interlayer (c Ã) configurations, and H c2 ðT Þ displays a positive curvature without saturation. This could be related to the wide pressure range of the coexistence between the spin density wave (SDW) and superconductivity (SC) ground state, and may be caused by an FFLO state, for a magnetic field along the a-and b 0-axes with T ! 0:5 K for P ¼ 4:48 GPa. This feature is suppressed with increasing pressure when the orbital pair breaking mechanism becomes dominant. The Ginzburg-Landau coherence lengths for three different axes obtained from this work show that (TMTTF) PF 6 is an anisotropic three-dimensional superconductor.

The Bechgaard salt (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 (TMTSF = tetramethyltetraselenafulvalene) was the first organic superconductor discovered in 1980 with a superconducting temperature of T c ¼ 0:9 K (critical pressure, P c ¼ 1:2 GPa). 1) Since this discovery, materials based on TMTSF and its derivatives, such as TMTTF (tetramethyltetrathiofulvalene), the so-called (TMTCF) 2 X (X = monovalent anion) series, have been investigated extensively to search for other superconducting behaviors. [2][3][4][5] They have also attracted attention owing to their rich properties such as spin-Peierls (SP), charge-ordering, spin density wave (SDW), and possible unconventional superconductivity (SC) that appear by changing the counter anion or by applying external pressure. 6) Many compounds with TMTSF molecules exhibit an SC state at low pressures of approximately 1 GPa, 6,7) whereas most compounds with TMTTF exhibit an SC transition at ultra high pressures, for example, P c ¼ 5 GPa in (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 . 8,9) Taking advantage of the low pressure induced 10) and ambient pressure 11,12) superconductivity, studies especially of the SC phase and its upper critical field have been conducted extensively with TMTSF salts, but rarely with TMTTF salts.

A generic phase diagram was obtained through studies of many different materials among the TMTCF series at ambient and high pressures, combining the trends seen with chemical and external pressures. 3,5,7) The (chemical) pressure that each material displays in the phase diagram shows the degrees of three-dimensionality caused by many factors such as the size of the anion, the distance between molecular planes, distance between selenium or sulfur atoms and the Coulomb repulsion between conducting electrons. However, for layered organic materials such as TMTCF salts, the a-axis direction is most compressive where TMTCF planes have a weak van der Waals bonding due to the overlapping orbitals; it is least compressive along the c-axis direction where the TMTCF molecule and anion have ion bonding, even though the applied external pressure is highly hydrostatic. In the case of (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 , the lattice parameter a is decreased by 0.5%/kbar, while the normal directions are one order of magnitude less compressive 13) when 3 kbar (0.3 GPa) of hydrostatic pressure is applied. Therefore, even with hydrostatic pressure, the electronic structure changes anisotropically; the dimensionality of the system also changes, and the amplitude of the change varies depending on the size of the anion and the type of cation. It is an open question whether chemical pressure and external pressure can be treated in exactly the same manner. Therefore, by changing the external pressure on different designer molecules to gather information, one expects to achieve a universal understanding of quasi-one-dimensional organic conductors.

Owing to the technical difficulty in applying hydrostatic pressure to fragile organic compounds at low temperatures in magnetic fields, the anisotropy of the upper critical field (H c2 ) in TMTTF salts had not been determined prior to this work. In the present work, the anisotropy of H c2 in (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 was determined via resistivity at tempera-tures as low as T ¼ 0:5 K and at magnetic fields of up to 5 T, which also complements previous reports. 9,14) 2. Experimental Procedure Single crystals of (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 were synthesized by the electrochemical method. 15) The dimensions of the crystal selected for resistivity measurements were $150 Â 30 Â 20 m 3 . The electrical resistivity was measured by the standard four-probe method with an AC current range from 1 to A parallel to the a-axis (intrachain). This measurement was carried out in a He refrigerator located in a 10 T magnet. Pressure was generated using a turnbuckle-type diamond anvil cell (DAC). The diamond culets are 0.9 mm in diameter and separated by a gasket indented to 65 m that has a 300 m hole as a sample chamber. Details of this pressure apparatus are discussed elsewhere. 16) Graphite paint was used to make electrical contacts between the leads of pressed gold wires (10 m in diameter) and the sample. The sample was placed inside a cavity with a liquid pressure medium, glycerin, which was proven to transmit a nearly hydrostatic pressure of up to GPa, 17) in the gasket, which is placed between the two diamonds. The pressure is calibrated at T ¼ 77 K by monitoring the shift in the fluorescence of a ruby chip located in the cavity near the sample. 18) The DAC used in this study tends to gain pressure as it is cooled down from room temperature to a temperature below liquid nitrogen temperature where the pressure stabilizes. During the measurements of H k b 0 , the sample in a DAC was warmed up to a temperature above the liquid nitrogen temperature a few times, which induced different normal state resistances. It is extremely difficult to calculate the absolute value of resistivity by transport measurement when using a DAC with organic materials. This is due to the amount of conducting paint, which is relatively large for a small sample, and the inaccurate determination of the distance between contacts and the cross sectional area of the sample. Therefore, we used the data from the resistivity measurement of a crystal from the same batch using a cubic anvil press for pressurization to normalize our data. 14) The pressure dependence of the resistivity at T ¼ 285 K obtained using the cubic anvil press shows a range from 0.04-0.0015 cm as the pressure is increased from 0-10 GPa. These values were used to determine the resistivity in the DAC.

A magnetic field was applied along the a-, b 0 -, and c Ã -axes and the temperature dependence of the resistivity was measured in the pressure range of P ¼ 4:37{5:64 GPa at low temperatures. The orientation of the sample was adjusted by changing the angles of the DAC for each measurement point.

The temperature dependence of the resistivity of (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 is shown in a log-log plot for 0:79 P 6:96 GPa (Fig. 1). The local minimum of resistivity observed at approximately 240 K for P ¼ 0:79 GPa disappears with pressure application. The insulating behavior is gradually suppressed at higher pressures, and a metallic temperature dependence appears in the high-temperature range, followed by a low-temperature insulating behavior above P ¼ 2:55 GPa. The metal-insulator (M-I) transition temperature shifts to lower values as pressure is increased and reaches 8.6 K for P ¼ 4:18 GPa. The resistivity in the insulating region shows a sharp drop mediated by the SC transition at approximately 2 K for 4.18 GPa. The highest SC transition temperature is T c ¼ 2:25 K at 4.58 GPa, and no SC transition was observed above P ¼ 6:96 GPa. We define the local minimum temperature at 0.79 GPa as T , and estimated T s from the local minimum of @ ln ðT Þ=@T , where ðT Þ is the temperature-dependent resistivity.

T c was defined by the onset temperature of the sharp drop of resistivity (see arrows in Fig. 1). Figure 2 highlights the low-temperature SC transition. Within the temperature range in the present work, the presence of zero resistance was confirmed at approximately 1.5 K in the pressure range of 4:18 P 4:58 GPa, which was not previously observed. 8,9) This supports the hypothesis that the pressures generated in the DAC used here are as hydrostatic as those of a cubic anvil press, which was the only pressure apparatus that allowed zero resistance to be observed in this material. 14) The finite width of the SC transition is considered a fluctuation effect in a low-dimensional system. The fluctuation effect associated with transitions cannot be ignored in low-dimensional systems; the superconductivity is destroyed at a finite temperature, producing a finite resistance. This resistance decreases exponentially as temperature drops, so the decrease in the resistance is clearly shown right below the T c . This is considered as the origin of the broad transition in our case, and this behavior is typical of organic superconductors. With increased pressure, even broader transitions are observed, probably owing to the suppression of spin fluctuations which will be discussed later in this section. Hump structures seen below T c have not been observed in earlier works. 8,9,14) We attribute these structures to an inhomogeneous SC state that probably results from structural deformation by nonuniform pressures generated by the DAC, and/or form microcracks due to the extremely brittle nature of the sample. The inhomogeneous state is not an intrinsic property.

In a generic pressure-temperature (P-T ) phase diagram, 3,5,19) the ground state of (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 becomes an AF/SDW from SP at approximately 1 GPa, and then an SC phase at approximately 4.3 GPa. The local minimum of the resistance appears at approximately 400 K at ambient pressure; this is referred to as the charge localized (CL) or Mott transition. Using these values, T and T s are defined by the gap formations of CL and SDW, respectively. Figure 3 shows the P-T phase diagram obtained in this work. Note that open symbols represent data cited from ref. 20 to show the likely regions of CL and SP. With increasing pressure, the nesting of the Fermi surface is broken and the SDW phase is suppressed. T s drops drastically at approximately P ¼ 3 GPa and disappears at the critical pressure of approximately P ¼ 4:5 GPa. This is also clearly seen at higher pressures, where the normal state appears to be metallic at 4.58 GPa and slightly localized at 4.37 GPa (Fig. 3). Above P ¼ 4:37 GPa, metallic behavior is observed over the entire temperature range. The highest T c was observed near the pressure at which the SDW phase vanished. The SC phase in the vicinity of the SDW phase was observed at 4:18 P 6:03 GPa. The emergence of superconductivity, which competes with the SDW state at 4:18 P 4:37 GPa, appears to be a general behavior among (TMTCF) 2 X superconductors. The origin of superconductivity in this family is considered to be produced by spin fluctuations developed in Cooper pairs similar to heavyfermion systems 21) since an antiferro-magnetic spin fluctuation develops in the normal state. Our data also supports the theory that the spin fluctuation in the SDW state is enhanced by the formation of an SC state. TMTTF salts have a higher T c and a higher P c than TMTSF salts. The higher T c is a result of the smaller bandwidth due to the smaller transfer integrals, which in turn increases the density of states. This feature appears as the anion size dependence for the -BEDT-TTF group. 22)

There are two independent mechanisms of suppressing superconductivity with magnetic fields. One is the orbital breaking of Cooper pairs in the superconducting state associated with screening currents generated to exclude the external field (orbital limit), which becomes dominant first for most superconductors. The other is a spin effect due to Zeeman splitting, which applies only to singlet pairings and limits superconductivity below the Pauli or Clogston-Chandrasekhar limit, 23,24) as given by the weak-coupling BCS paramagnetic formula

where Á 0 is the superconducting gap at T ¼ 0 K and B is Bohr magneton for isotropic s-wave pairing in the absence of spin-orbit scattering. This relation is a good guide for determining whether or not the system is a triplet superconductor. The anisotropy of H c2 in (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 was determined by Lee et al. 25) The magnitude of H c2 was more than four times the Pauli limit and there was no change in the NMR Knight shift. These results supported the view that this system is a triplet superconductor. However, after that, a clear change of the Knight shift was observed for the superconductivity of (TMTSF) 2 ClO 4 at T c , revealing that it is in the singlet state at lower fields. 26) Yonezawa et al. 27) concluded that (TMTSF) ClO 4 is a singlet superconductor and exhibits an FFLO state at high fields by a careful study of the in-plane anisotropy of T c . Aizawa et al. showed that consecutive transitions from the singlet pairing to the FFLO state and further to the S z ¼ 1 triplet pairing can generally take place upon increasing the magnetic field in the vicinity of the SDW+CDW coexisting phase; they also postulated (TMTSF) 2 X as a candidate material that exhibits this property. 28) Data of resistivity vs temperature at P ¼ 4:37{4:58 GPa and with the field along three different axes are shown in Fig. 4. For H k a and c Ã , the resistivity in the normal state at zero applied field does not vary as the magnetic field is increased, and the transition temperatures are depressed to lower values. For H k b 0 at P ¼ 4:37 and 4.96 GPa, the pressures rose by approximately 0.4% during the thermal cycling owing to the differential contraction of the pressure cell. It only happens for H k b 0 , as it was the first orientation measured after each pressurization. The effect of the change in pressure on the normal state resistivity becomes obvious near the critical pressure; therefore, it can only be seen at P ¼ 4:37 GPa. The pressure rose from 4.37 to 4.58 GPa during this particular measurement for H k b 0 . This explains the higher resistance in Fig. 4(b) than in Figs. 4(a) and 4(c). Also a small localization can be seen in the curves for H ¼ 0{0:19 T, and an even smaller localization in the curves for H ¼ 0:29{1:59 T. In our measured temperature range, no SC was detected above 2.2 T along the a-and b 0 -axes and above 0.39 T for the c Ã -axis. Another possible interpretation for this upturn, particularly for the H c2 ðT Þ curve at P ¼ 4:58 GPa, could be related to the wide pressure range of the coexistence between the SDW and SC ground states as observed for H k c Ã in (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 . 25) For a thin superconducting layer, the upper critical field in a field parallel to the layer is greatly enhanced with the relation H c2 $ ð=dÞH c , where d is the layer thickness, is the penetration depth, and H c is the thermodynamic critical field. 31) In the new model proposed by Lee et al., the formation and reconstruction of SDW/ superconductor domains occur taking advantage of the largest penetration depth. 25) Their model seems to be consistent with our data since the deviation from the GL fit decreases as the pressure increases or as the system is moved further from the SDW phase.

The anisotropies of H c2 for P ¼ 4:48, 5.10, and 5.64 GPa obtained using the onset criterion is shown in Fig. 6. Owing to the difficulty in achieving exactly the same pressure at low temperatures for each thermal cycle, the plots for all the axes that show similar T c values at zero field are compared in the same figure, even though the pressures are slightly different. The pressure difference is less than 3%. A positive curvature without saturation as T decreases can be seen for H k a and H k b 0 , and the curves for H k a and H k b 0 are almost on top of each other at P ¼ 4:48 GPa in this temperature range. Interestingly, a similar trend is observed in (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 25) and (TMTSF) 2 ClO 4 ; 27) H a c2 ðT Þ % H b 0 c2 ðT Þ ) H c Ã c2 ðT Þ, except in the absence of isotropic features in the low field range in the present work. However, H c2 ðT Þ curves were anisotropic in the ab 0 -plane in the case of (TMTSF) SbF 6 , which will be published elsewhere. When the field is applied along the c Ã -axis, orbital limiting dominates because the field penetrates the ab 0 -plane and decouples the Cooper pairs. However it is unusual for the curve of H k b 0 to be on top of H k a, not showing any anisotropy at all where the transfer integral t b 0 is smaller than t a by one order of magnitude at ambient pressure.

Also a complete structural study of (TMTSF) 2 PF 6 and (TMTSF) 2 ClO 4 up to approximately 1 GPa was reported by Gallois et al. 33) The ab-plane anisotropy could be predicted using the independent molecular mean distances between TMTSF molecules in intra-and inter-chains. The interchain distances were better compressed than the intrachain distances from 0.01 to 0.98 GPa. The spacial distance between Se atoms in the b-axis were only about 0.16 # A longer than that in the a-axis at 1 GPa. In our case, we applied a very high pressure for (TMTTF) PF 6 , so that the anisotropy in ab 0 -plane at 4 GPa will be well suppressed. However, the use of different types of pressure apparatus markedly affects the change in crystal structure. Furthermore, the present data imply a large pressure effect in resistivity up to P ¼ 4:37 GPa, as seen in Fig. 1. One may consider from this isotropy that paramagnetic limiting dominates for both orientations, but as can be seen in Figs. 6(b) and 6(c), similar curves appear at higher pressures where the orbital limiting clearly dominates. Therefore, this feature seems universal among TMTCF salts. These results indicate that the present compound is an anisotropic three-dimensional superconductor that does not involve Josephson interaction. Note that these values might be underestimated owing to contribution of the paramagnetic limiting effect leading H c2 to have a smaller slope. Therefore, the coherence length for P ¼ 4:48 GPa could be slightly smaller if paramagnetic limiting is completely eliminated; however, it should not affect this estimation. The ratio of transfer integrals along each axis are estimated to be t a : t b 0 : t c Ã ¼ 300 : 10 : 1 at ambient pressure and room temperature, whereas according to our data, within the pressure and temperature range superconductivity is observed, the strong one-dimensional feature is suppressed and dimensionality is increased. The conductivities along the a-and b 0 -axes are about the same and larger than that of the c Ã -axis by a factor of 10-30. With increasing pressure, m c Ã increases. This is consistent with the results of Morosin et al., 13) given that the compressibility is smaller along the c Ã -axis where a TMTTF molecule and an anion form an ionic bond than along the a-axis where orbits of TMTTF are overlapped with a van der Waals bonding. Also note that a superconductivity appeared with uniaxial strain along the a-axis but not with that perpendi-cular to the a-axis in the case of (TMTSF) PF 6 . These results implied that compression along the a-axis direction leads to an increase in interchain transfer integrals with a reduction in the diagonal distance of TMTSF molecules. [34][35][36]

We have conducted transport measurement by using a turnbuckle-type DAC on (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 under multi-extreme conditions which was previously difficult to achieve. (TMTTF) 2 X has a higher critical pressure exceeding the range of widely used piston cylinder cells, and for this reason few observations of superconductivity have been reported. We have observed superconductivity in (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 with an actual zero resistivity at P ¼ 4:18{4:58 GPa. In this compound, zero resistivity was never observed in the SC phase in other high pressure studies using a regular DAC or Bridgman pressure cell (BAC) with a solid pressure medium. However, better results, including zero resistivity in the SC state, have been obtained recently in BAC with a liquid pressure medium in (TMTTF) BF 4 . 37) In (TMTTF) 2 PF 6 , only measurements with a cubic anvil press, which generates highly hydrostatic pressures, showed superconductivity with zero resistivity, 14) indicating that our measurement with a DAC has similar accuracy to that with a cubic anvil press. The SC dome lies at P ¼ 4:18{6:18 GPa in the P-T phase diagram obtained from this work, and the highest transition temperature was T c ¼ 2:25 K. Our data extended the ranges of temperatures and pressures and supplemented the reported P-T phase diagram.

We have also measured the temperature dependence of H c2 along the three axes on (TMTTF) PF 6 and shown that H c2 displays a positive curvature without saturation, which may be attributed to an FFLO state, for a magnetic field along the a-and b 0 -axes at T ! 0:5 K for P ¼ 4:48 GPa. We also have shown that the upturn feature is suppressed with increasing pressure and the orbital pair breaking mechanism becomes dominant. In further studies of the pair breaking mechanism, measurement should be conducted at lower temperatures and with more refined pressure control. Our data above T ¼ 0:5 K shows that H c2 slightly exceeds the Pauli paramagnetic limit at P ¼ 4:48 GPa for H k a. H c2 curves for H k a and H k b 0 lie on top of each other indicating that it has a two-dimensional-like feature, being isotropic within the ab 0 -plane.
